bestBHT.bht: Death dissolves legal obligation. While a woman will be called an adulteress if she is married to another man while her husband is alive, there can be no exception if her husband is dead. In this case, she is free from the law and no longer faces the imputation of adultery.

Henry Alford: But when we come to the application of the example, this must carefully be borne in mind, as tending to clear up all the confusion.
The Apostle is insisting on the fact that death dissolves legal obligation: but he is not drawing an exact parallel between the persons in his example and the persons in his application.
Albert Barnes: She shall be called - She will be."
The word used here χρηματίσει chrēmatisei is often used to denote being called by an oracle or by divine revelation.
But it is here employed in the simple sense of being commonly called, or of being so regarded.
Marvin Vincent: She shall be called [χρηματισει] . See on Acts 11:26.
Philip Schaff: Shall be called an adulteress... The verse forms a parallelism."
Free from that law... the binding effect of the law as respects the marriage relation."
So that she is not an adulteress... the purpose of this freedom was to prevent the woman from being an adulteress in case of a second marriage.
Archibald T. Robertson: She shall be called... to receive a name.
It is a fact... for result.
John Gill: True indeed it is, that whilst her husband is alive, if she be married to another man, she shall be called an adulteress; she will be noted and accounted of as such."
but if her husband be dead; then there can be no exception to her marriage: she is free from the law;
so that she is no adulteress; nor will any reckon her such; she is clear from any such imputation: though she be married to another man.

bhtAttempts.bht: When examining the example given by the Apostle Paul, it becomes clear that death dissolves legal obligation. Though he is not drawing an exact parallel between the example and the application, the principle remains the same – while the husband is alive, if a woman is married to another man, she will be called an adulteress. However, if her husband is dead, there can be no exception to her marriage, and she is free from the law, no longer facing the imputation of adultery.

When examining the example given by the Apostle Paul, we see that death dissolves legal obligation. While a woman will be called an adulteress if she is married to another man while her husband is alive, there is no exception to her marriage if her husband is dead. In this case, she is free from the law and no longer faces the imputation of adultery.

Death dissolves legal obligation. While a woman will be called an adulteress if she is married to another man while her husband is alive, there can be no exception if her husband is dead. In this case, she is free from the law and no longer faces the imputation of adultery.

When considering the example given, it is important to remember that death dissolves legal obligation. The Apostle is emphasizing this point, without drawing an exact parallel between the example and the application. In the case described, if a woman is married to another man while her husband is alive, she will be called an adulteress. However, if her husband dies, then there is no exception to her marriage and she is free from the law. In this situation, she will not be considered an adulteress.
